name: Ruff
description: Ruffs are medium-sized waders with remarkable sexual dimorphism. Males differ from females not only in larger size but, during the breeding season, especially by a rich feather ruff around the neck. It can be white, rusty, or nearly black. Together with elongated head feathers, orange bare facial patches, and a black chest spot, it serves as an eye-catching signal during their ostentatious courtship display, attracting females and intimidating rivals.
spread_note: Breeds in northern Eurasia, winters in western and southern Europe, Africa, South Asia, and Australia
food_note: Invertebrates, plant parts at wintering grounds
proportions: Body length 20–32 cm; wingspan 46–58 cm; weight 70–250 g
attractions: During the breeding season, males gather at traditional lek sites, where dominant males often return for years. Satellite males lack their own territory but use the edges of the dominant males’ lek areas. Ruffs nest on the ground in shallow depressions hidden in vegetation.
breeding: In the modern history of the zoo, we have kept them since 2010, though it’s not ruled out that they were kept earlier.
